Instruction: Prepare the Vegetables
Wash and Cut Vegetables: Wash and cut your chosen vegetables into bite-sized pieces suitable for frying. Aim for uniform thickness for even cooking.
Optional Drying: Pat the vegetables dry with paper towels to remove any excess moisture. This helps the batter adhere better and prevents splatter during frying.
Make the Tempura Batter
Whisk Dry Ingredients: In a large bowl
Separate Egg Yolk (Optional): If using an egg yolk, separate it from the egg white. You can use the leftover egg white for another recipe.
Create a Well: Make a well in the center of the dry ingredients.

Incorporate Cold Water: Slowly whisk in the ice-cold water, starting with ¾ cup.  **Tip:** Add the water gradually to achieve the desired batter consistency. The batter should be slightly thick but still pourable. It should coat the back of a spoon without being too heavy or gloopy.
Add Egg Yolk (Optional): If using, whisk in the egg yolk at this point.
"Important:  Avoid Overmixing. Do not overmix the batter. A few lumps are okay; overmixing can make the tempura tough."
Tempura Frying

Heat Oil: In a large pot or Dutch oven, heat the oil over medium-high heat to 350°F. You can check the oil temperature with a thermometer or by dropping a small piece of batter; it should sizzle and float to the surface within seconds.

Dip and Fry (Small Batches): Fry the vegetables in small batches to avoid overcrowding the pan and lowering the oil temperature. Dip each vegetable piece into the batter, coating it completely but letting any excess drip back into the bowl.
Carefully Transfer to Oil: Carefully lower the battered vegetables into the hot oil. Don't overcrowd the pan. Fry for 1-2 minutes per side, or until golden brown and crispy.
Drain and Transfer: Using a slotted spoon or spider strainer, transfer the fried vegetables to a paper towel-lined plate to drain any excess oil.
Serve and Enjoy
Season (Optional): While still hot, sprinkle the tempura vegetables with a pinch of kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper (optional).
Serve Hot: Serve the tempura vegetables hot immediately with your favorite dipping sauce like tempura dipping sauce, soy sauce with wasabi, or ponzu sauce. Enjoy!**
Tips:
You can adjust the frying time depending on the thickness of your vegetables. Thicker vegetables will require a longer frying time.
If the tempura batter becomes too thick while frying, whisk in a tablespoon or two of ice-cold water to thin it out slightly.

Leftover tempura vegetables can be stored in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to 1 day. However, they may lose some of their crispness. Reheat them in a preheated oven at 350°F for a few minutes to try and restore some crispness.
